. Hi, thanks for the pull request. One of the two offending delegates is addressed by changes from the recent 3.0 update. However, the other one still stands, and we will include a fix to it in the next update. Thanks for the improvement to the SDK!
. Thanks for the pull request! We recognize that JSON libraries are a pain point in the SDK and have been for a while. Unfortunately the recent 3.0 update did not improve this. In fact, now that we are packaging the SDK as a framework (implying linking, rather than compiling the SDK into your app), there is a new wrinkle in the problem. The solutions available to us appear to be:
A) A fix along the lines of this diff -- where for projects where you compile the code it is easy to swap-out the JSON bits
B) A fix that allows "binary" swapping of the JSON parser, via some abstraction -- so that users of the framework also get the flexibility to swap out the parser
B') Same as B, but with an included version of SBJSON for the users that doesn't care to swap out -- but renaming classes to avoid collisions.
C) Wait until 5.0 is the lowest supported level, and move the implementation to NSJSONSerialization.
On the surface, B or B' seem like the most useful solution, however B has the negative side effect of making everyone include a JSON library on their own even if their needs are very simple, and B' has a bloat problem -- though maybe that doesn't matter much?
Would love to hear your opinions :)
. Thanks @stig for the thoughts. I think the dependencies instructions approach is certainly the most "correct" in the sense that that approach scales to any number of dependency codebases, etc.

. Hi Josh,
There are two ways to accomplish what you are shooting for here, with the existing SDK:
1) Create an FBRequest object with a nil session, and set the access_token parameter directly
2) Create an FBSession object, and pass in a custom TokenCachingStrategy object that lets you set the token explicitly for the session object (You can find an internal implementation of TokenCachingStrategy named ManualTokenCachingStrategy used by the Facebook class that does just this.)
Two feels a bit "design heavy" to me for simple needs, but if your app does a lot of page posting, it may be useful to have an FBSession object at the ready with the token in place. Unfortunately, there are a handful of reasons that accessToken is readonly.
To make this simpler in the SDK, we should probably just create a post helper (similar to [FBRequest requestForPostStatusUpdate]) which makes it easy to put together a request for posting to a page. What do you think?

. Hi @tylerberry, thanks for the pull request. We are also eager to reduce the number of libraries that we depend on in the SDK. Our plan is to eventually move to NSJSONSerialization, on the merits of being built into the OS. However, as long as we continue to support iOS 4.3, we are not able to move to the built in library.
I do understand the benchmark argument -- though we have not independently verified the performance difference. Between now and the point where we deprecate 4.3, I can see adding #define support for swapping out the SBJSON bits for anyone willing to build the SDK themselves, this would give an easy way to swap-out whatever library they want. I don't  believe we would try and make swapping an option for the lib, nor do we have plans to ship another library given that soon we should be able to use the OS. Do you think the #define interim solution adds enough value to consider?

PEZ:
Forgot to mention that I needed to make some changes to Facebook.m too to be able to create an FBRequest without also connecting the request at the same time. This is an example of usage within a Three20 datamodel:
FBRequest* fbRequest = [fb getRequestWithGraphPath:@"me/home" andDelegate:nil];
TTURLRequest* request = [TTURLRequest
                         requestWithURL: [fbRequest getConnectURL]
                         delegate: self];
...
[request send];
. Wonderful! FBConnect + Three20 is a match made in heaven. =)
. Using Three20's connections mechanism is much less work if your project is using Three20. That's if you want to use three20's TTTableViewController which makes it really smooth to consume an API and render it using the TTURLRequestModel, TTDataSource, TTItemCell, TTTableItem etcetera framework.
There's a (somewhat confused) discussion on the challenges involved here: https://groups.google.com/d/topic/three20/Yyj-FhUoZUI/discussion
Note that this feature request is not only about three20. People use all kinds of frameworks where it is easier to follow the Tao if just FBConnect is ready to serve as "factory" for constructing the URLs for the API calls.
BTW, I use FBConnect directly for many calls. It's great. It's when it needs to coexist within the framework I'm using that it helps having this make-this-fbrequest-url-for-me-please interface.
. TTTableViewController works with TTModel subclasses. It's definitely possible to make a subclass and wrap FBConnect in it. Just that it did not look trivial to me when I took a look at it. TTURLRequestModel is there and ready for use if you just know what URLs to feed to it. For me it was much less work and much easier to add an interface to FBConnect like I did.
So, this feature request isn't sprung out of necessity. Rather convenience. Then again, that's how I see FBConnect, as a convenience library.
Of course, I'm really a newbie when it comes to three20. It's entirely possible that I have missed something. (Even if that groups discussion didn't unearth any immediate solution either.)

Hi,
In the simulator there is no Facebook application installed. The natural behavior of the SDK is to call Safari if the Facebook application is not installed. This behavior is not a modified by my patch. 
You say you do not return back to the test app : What is the content of the Safari page loaded ? Is it a Facebook login page or a Facebook confirmation page ? Can you tap on a "confirm" or "ok" button, and if yes, what happens ?

Sébastien. 
. Have you added the appropriate URL Schemes in the DemoApp-Info.list ? 
. If you set  safariAuth:NO in the simulator, I think you are going to have the old authentication method (with and UIWebView). 
Why did you start with my fork instead of the main repository ?
. Yes, you should add something like that in your DemoApp-Info.list, where [app-id] is your facebook app id. 
<key>CFBundleURLTypes</key>
<array>
    <dict>
        <key>CFBundleURLName</key>
        <string></string>
        <key>CFBundleURLSchemes</key>
        <array>
            <string>fb[app-id]</string>
        </array>
    </dict>
</array>
. You're welcome.

maciekish:
I ran into this issue as well. Unless i got the basic understanding of delegates wrong i think this should be merged..
However, wouldn't this cause a retain loop in certain cases?
Edit 3: Even though i like the simplicity of removing bugs the above way, i think the root cause of the crash is the delegate being released while there is an outstanding request and the crash should be fixed by either not making the original delegate not go away, or cancel all outstanding requests before it does. Second solution can be implemented by keeping all your requests in an array and running through it on dealloc sending each request the cancel message. This will prevent a callback to a released delegate AND any retain loops which could be caused by the change from assign to retain. Im no expert though, just my 5 cents, correct me if im wrong.

adamjernst:
+1, this should definitely be fixed.
. Failing to nil out delegates is a bug, plain and simple. You may or may not see crashes since memory misuse causes nondeterministic failures. You may even see weird behavior like crashes disappearing when you disable an unrelated library, since it will change the pattern of allocations and deallocations.
Regardless, this is a bug in Facebook's SDK and should be fixed.

. Thanks for the submission! That's a good point that the app's UIApplication delegate should default to returning YES. The original intention of our implementation is to return YES only if the URL was recognized and handled by the FBSDK. So it seems like our real problem is that our docs and samples prescribe return [FBSDKApplicationDelegate sharedInstance] application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:] when instead they should be
[FBSDKApplicationDelegate sharedInstance] application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:];
  return YES;
in the general case.
Then advanced cases could be like
if ([FBSDKApplicationDelegate sharedInstance] application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:]) { 
         //FB Handled, can short-circuit
        return YES;
    }
    // else do any other custom logic with URLs
    return YES.
Does that make sense or am I overlooking something else?
. > If the URL is recognized by FBSDK and handled in -application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: (as it is now), then it's appropriate to return NO
I don't think that's correct. Apple docs say 

Return Value
NO if the app cannot handle the URL resource or continue a user activity, otherwise return YES

So if the SDK did handle the URL, we definitely should return YES. As mentioned I think the problem is our samples and docs saying to return the FBSDKApplicationDelegate result, when it should not in cases where developers do custom logic. 
Your workaround of passing nil will prevent the SDK from completing a login flow from a cold start case (i.e., app is killed while user is in Facebook app completing Login Dialog). Instead, you should  just always return YES unless there are specific URLs your app should not handle.
. > If the app returns YES from didFinishLaunching and it was launched via a URL (e.g. install, kill, and enter launchtest://foo in Safari) then openURL: will be called. If it returns NO, then openURL: won't be called.
Right, that's documented under the application:openURL:options: docs,

The return values of those methods can be used to prevent this method from being called. (If the app is already running, only this method is called.)

So we're still correct in that we should definitely return YES in didFinishLaunching if the SDK handled it. I'll work on updating our samples and docs so that developers should not return the [FBSDKApplicationDelegate application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:] result directly.
. FBSDKApplicationDelegate can only report if the URL was handled by FBSDK. It should not be the final return value for the app delegate's application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: - hence my point that we need to update our samples/docs to stop this bad behavior.
Technically you're right that in the FB login case, the URL would not need to be passed again to the openURL: (technically an implementation detail that could change) but other apps may want to still do some work in openURL:. The FBSDK url handling logic should be idempotent so it should not matter if it was processed already in the didFinishLaunch. 
And returning NO if the URL was handled is opposite of the aforementioned documentation and would probably lead to more confusion.
So to be clear, our samples/docs will be updated to read
- (BOOL)application:(UIApplication *)application didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:(NSDictionary *)launchOptions
{
    [[FBSDKApplicationDelegate sharedInstance] application:application
                             didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:launchOptions];
    return YES;
}
which would have also helped you avoid this problem in the first place.
. All the docs and samples should be updated now. Thanks for bringing this to our attention.

tylerberry:
There was another pull request (prior to the 3.0 release, I believe) which did that. The request was turned down due to the pending changes, I believe.
However, benchmarks show that SBJSON is a very slow Cocoa JSON implementation compared to JSONKit and NSJSONSerialization. For me personally, my app doesn't support iOS <5. But if you need a robust solution for iOS 4+, I'd personally strongly recommend cutting SBJSON anyway for this reason and integrating JSONKit as the fallback (or as the only option, given that JSONKit slightly outperforms NSJSONSerialization) instead. You could start with this pull, add fallbacks similar to the previously mentioned pull request, and for bonus points rename JSONKit in a similar fashion to this commit.
I might try to make a pull request for that, but I don't need the feature myself so it's not a high priority thing for me. :)
. It looks like there are actually C preprocessor macros already defined for this, so it would be pretty easy:
```
if __IPHONE_OS_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED >= __IPHONE_5_0
// Use NSJSONSerialization
elif __IPHONE_OS_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED >= __IPHONE_4_3
// Use bundled FBSBJSON
else
error The Facebook iOS SDK does not support iOS targets older than iOS 4.3.
endif
```
I'm assuming that Xcode guarantees that the __IPHONE_OS_VERSION_MIN_REQUIRED macro is magically defined based on your build settings, because otherwise it wouldn't really make much sense. Full disclosure, I just Googled this, I haven't tested it to verify. :)

This is a crashing bug, not just a memory leak.
My application is deployed with a patched SDK build because of the issue. (Same with #507, which doesn't directly cause a crash, but does cause serious misbehaviour).
. Then there are several major bugs:
1) It may be retained and called on subsequent, unrelated state changes.
2) There is no way to clear it.
3) The single loginHandler may be overwritten on subsequent 'openWith…' calls without the original one ever being triggered.
4) It's erroneously labeled a completion handler, when it is not one.
The behaviour is completely unpredictable: the "completion handler" may be called zero, one, or more times. There is no public-interface way to clear a loginHandler nor can you reliably wait for one to terminate—it might have been overwritten anyway—and you can't use it for one-off actions for success/failure. Unless this has changed significantly in 3.2 (I haven't had a chance to look), it's completely broken for common use cases.

vantonevich:
Well, the bug was about cleaning up the delegate references which you guys do not, in both cases. Not able to reproduce does not make that dangling pointer valid. Also, tried looking hard at those 6 lines and failed not to see _cacheIndex being released.
On 2013-07-24, at 12:26 PM, Chris Pan notifications@github.com wrote:

Thanks for the request. I'm not able to reproduce your crash and _cacheIndex does need a release when the FBDataDiskCache is deallocated. If you still see this behavior, can you file a bug at developers.facebook.com/bugs with the "ios sdk" tag. If you can, please include additional information (such as the stack trace or public API you were invoking). Thanks.
—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
. Not actually related to observed crashes but consistent with the need to cleanup delegate pointer once delegate itself gets deallocated
.
Blahartinger:
I can confirm this has happened to many of our users for our app, Vouchr (http://www.vouc.hr/), and I'm going to be quite happy to accept this patch in our included build of the sdk. This part of the code is very messy and your own comments suggest that it's an extremely bad and dangerous patten that you are obviously aware of and are trying to migrate away from even. Please consider this patch again or clean up this code. Leaving it how it is now is pretty irresponsible on Facebook's part. 
Also, I might add that ARC has been out for years now and you should probably consider migrating your code to it - nobody cares about pre 4.3 support anyway. I'm forking your repository now because of this, perhaps I'll consider starting the work for you.
.

same problem ... they should fix SDK FBDialog 
    if ([url.scheme isEqualToString:@"fbconnect"]) {

fbconnect://cancel is never called

fbconnect://success?request=&to[0]=<..id>
so with your fix in this case dialogDidCancel: will be called

jmah:
If the URL is recognized by FBSDK and handled in -application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: (as it is now), then it's appropriate to return NO. An alternative is to not handle the URL in didFinishLaunching, return YES, and handle it when the app delegate passes through -application:openURL:…. However the URL handling logic on launch and after launch look superficially quite different, so I'm not sure that's equivalent.
My workaround for the moment has been to pass nil options to application:didFinishLaunchingWithOptions: and always return YES, and hope that any Facebook stuff would be handled in the openURL: callback. (That approach should work both before and after this patch.) But I'm doubtful now if FBSDKLoginManager gets correctly invoked by doing this. Can you provide any insight?
In your "advanced cases" snippet, the delegate should actually be returning NO in both of those instances — if the app delegate can handle the URL on launch, then it doesn't also need to receive the -application:openURL:… delegate callback.
. The docs are poorly written and I think incorrect in this case. I made a sample project (linked) to verify the behavior. If the app returns YES from didFinishLaunching and it was launched via a URL (e.g. install, kill, and enter launchtest://foo in Safari) then openURL: will be called. If it returns NO, then openURL: won't be called.

landonturner:
While I don't think your proposed change is a security risk because transposing + with " " doesn't collide with other base64 characters, it feels like this doesn't address the root cause of why the value is wrong.
What about making the change here and not use URLDecode when parsing the challenge?. Thank you for stepping through this. Ah yes, I see. The offending call to URLDecode happens much further upstream. Because this string is already decoded calling URLDecode again here is useless if not blatantly harmful. If the server sends the b64 URLEncoded encoded string abc%2d decoding once gives abc+d and twice gives abc d. This seems to not really matter so much in our case as it appears that the api server is not sending the challenge back as a URLEncoded string.
There are two options imo, send a URLEncoded string from the api and decode only one time, or replace the " " with a "+" when decoding the challenge parameter to undo the URLDecode as early as possible in the challenge string's lifecycle..
rinat-enikeev:
While I don't think your proposed change is a security risk because transposing + with " " doesn't collide with other base64 characters, it feels like this doesn't address the root cause of why the value is wrong.
What about making the change here and not use URLDecode when parsing the challenge?

It's too late. Challenge is already URLDecoded at this moment. FBSDKLoginManager calls FBSDKUtility where url string is decoded. 
This happens before the code line you provided. 
. I've double checked. 
The app receives URL as an encoded string. For example: 
URL (received): challenge%22%3A%22bg74itOTy8LAeb%20lQWdCK6r__QQ%3D%22. 
Decoded (received): "challenge\":\"bg74itOTy8LAeb lQWdCK6r__QQ=\"

valeriyvan:
You are right.
It seems static analyzer was false positive here.
I have added nonnull annotation to internal method to help static analyzer and this solved issue.. In FBSDKWebViewAppLinkResolver.m on line 277 this method might be called with appLinkTargetWithURL parameter nil. Parameter is created on line 274 and it might be nil as you could see.
Run static analyzer.
It really helps to see things you think are impossible.
Or this parameter might be nil. 
Or caller code is wrong..
mdabbagh88:
@robtimp I tracked the encoding process but those chars did not encode correctly
Also this not a usual http request url, this is a deep link url because I am using the .native mode, so I think the Core Foundation method which responsible for encoding those chars for http request is not working here.
And for the deep linking we only prepare a url string to pass to the UIApplication openUrl method, so in this case the responsibility of encoding those chars is count on us.
Here is an example of the produced URL object which is passed to openUrl method:
This is the string representation
fbapi20130214://dialog/share?bridge_args={%22action_id%22%3A%225D955C26-B56C-4C80-9FAB-464AD8BBDF5D%22%2C%22app_name%22%3A%22Sidreh%22%2C%22sdk_version%22%3A%224.39.0%22}&method_args={%22dataFailuresFatal%22%3Afalse%2C%22shareUUID%22%3A%2296675258-29C5-4CDF-8658-2529E6777A07%22%2C%22messenger_link%22%3A%22https%3A\\%2F\\%2Fwww.google.com%22%2C%22link%22%3A%22https%3A\\%2F\\%2Fwww.google.com%22}&version=20130410
The method used to encode the url string with its parameter is:
https://github.com/facebook/facebook-objc-sdk/blob/master/FBSDKCoreKit/FBSDKCoreKit/Internal/FBSDKInternalUtility.m#L375
And
https://github.com/facebook/facebook-objc-sdk/blob/master/FBSDKCoreKit/FBSDKCoreKit/Internal/FBSDKInternalUtility.m#L108
And this method does not encode the parameter correctly.

samvoigt: Why the preference for GCD over NSOperationQueue here?. Change this to loadingIndicator. Change to showLoadingIndicator. Change to hideLoadingIndicator. If a user wants to search for just a space, that's ok, the SDK will just return things near the location.. This is for the current place confidence, and without it, you may get re-used cells that do not black when they should be..
